Title: Transforming Markets
Description: Notice Type:          Special Notice – REQUEST FOR INFORMATION (RFI) RFI Number:          RFI-522-17-00003 Subject:                 Transforming Market Systems Issuance Date:      June 23, 2017 Closing Date:         July 10, 2017   This is a Request for Information (RFI) pursuant to FAR Part 15.201(c), (d) and (f) and FAR Part 10.002 (b)(2)(iii). The purpose of this RFI is to:  §  invite comments regarding acquisition strategy (including contract type, terms and conditions, and acquisition planning schedules); feasibility of the requirement (including performance requirements, statements of work, and data requirements);  the availability of reference documents; and any other concerns or questions;   §  improve the understanding of Government requirements and industry capabilities, thereby allowing potential offerors to judge whether or how they can satisfy the Government’s requirements, and enhancing USAID/Honduras’ ability to obtain quality services at reasonable prices; and §  learn about the size, status and capability of potential sources.  An additional purpose of this RFI is to increase the efficiency in proposal preparation and evaluation, negotiation, and contract award in the event USAID/Honduras elects to issue a solicitation requesting proposals.   This is an RFI, not a Request for Proposals (RFP), and is not to be construed as a commitment by the U.S. Government to issue any solicitation or ultimately award a contract on the basis of this RFI, nor to pay for any information submitted as a result of this request, nor does it commit the Government to pay for costs incurred in the preparation and submission of any comments.      USAID requests that interested parties review and provide feedback on the attached documents, insights regarding feasibility of the outlined activity and any suggestions for clarifications of the requirements.  While there are no page limitations submissions should be concise and focused on the requirements.  Interested parties should submit their name, address, contact information, and information on business size and socio-economic status.  USAID requests that interested U.S. Small and Disadvantaged Businesses provide a capability statement specifically describing their ability to fulfill the requirements and outlining their experience in related areas.   USAID will not directly provide responses to any inquiries submitted based on this RFI.  Proprietary information should not be sent. USAID may use any information provided without incurring any obligations.   This RFI is issued to offer the opportunity for interested organizations and individuals to provide information, opinions, and recommendations on approaches for the implementation of the Transforming Market Systems single award IDIQ and Task Order No.1 as described in the attached draft Statements of Work.  Kindly submit responses to this RFI to Vann D. Rolfson, Contracting Officer, USAID/Honduras at oaahonduras@usaid.gov with the RFI No. RFI-522-17-00003 on the subject line.  Comments received prior to Monday, July 10, 2017 are more likely to receive consideration during mission planning.    Sincerely, Vann D. Rolfson Contracting Officer Attachments: CO letter signed in PDF SOW for Basic Single Award IDIQ and  SOW for Task Order No.1 KO
POC Information: Karla P Oviedo | Vann D. Rolfson
NAICS: All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services

Title: Support to Anti-Corruption Champion Institutions (SACCI) Program in Ukraine
Description: Pre-solicitation Notice   Support to Anti-Corruption Champion Institutions (SACCI) Program in Ukraine Solicitation Number: SOL-121-17-000002 Pre-solicitation Release Date:  October 19, 2016 The United States Government, represented by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), Regional Mission for Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova intends to issue a contract for the implementation of the Support to Anti-Corruption Champion Institutions (SACCI) Program in Ukraine. USAID intends to use full and open competition for this procurement and to release the solicitation within the first quarter of U.S. fiscal year 2017. This pre-solicitation notice purpose is to provide information regarding the anticipated USAID Support to Anti-Corruption Champion Institutions (SACCI) Program in Ukraine through a synopsis. Title: Support to Anti-Corruption Champion Institutions Program (SACCI) Purpose: The purpose of the Support to Anti-Corruption Champion Institutions Program (SACCI) is to reduce corruption and increase the accountability and transparency of governance in Ukraine. Objectives: Objective 1: Key Government Institutions Empowered to Fight Corruption Objective 2: Public Support for and Engagement in Anti-Corruption Efforts Increased Objective 3: Public Tolerance of Corrupt Practices Reduced Prospective Offerors are advised that this procurement is subject to internal USAID approvals and the availability of funds. This is NOT an Invitation for Bid (IFB) or a Request for Proposals (RFP) and in no way obligates the US Government to issue an RFP/IFB and/or award a contract. This notice satisfies the synopsis requirement in FAR 5.2. If a solicitation is issued, all necessary information will be supplied at the time it is posted at www.fbo.gov. Interested parties are advised to periodically monitor the above website and solicitation number for updates concerning this procurement.

Title: Technical Assistance to implement Reading For Success - National Program for Reading Project in Morocco
Description: Notice of Intent for the Reading For Success - National Program for Reading (RFS-NPR) Project THIS NOTICE OF INTENT (NOI) IS NOT A REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS (RFP). The purpose of this NOI is to provide advance notification that USAID/Morocco is contemplating issuing a Full and Open RFP within the next month. The offerors should use this opportunity to identify key personnel and establish preliminary teaming arrangements.   The resulting award will support USAID/Morocco's Reading For Success - National Program for Reading (RFS-NPR) Activity. This new award has an estimated cost between $17.5 million and $19.5 million over the course of 5 years with an anticipated award date in May 2017 with a rapid mobilization. Ability to rapidly mobilize in Morocco will be one of the evaluation criteria under the RFP. We anticipate this award to be a Cost- Plus-Fixed-Fee Completion type contract.   The Education Office in the United States Agency for International Development's Mission in Morocco requires technical services to implement the Reading For Success - National Program for Reading (RFS-NPR) Project in Morocco. The objective of the RFS-NPR activity is to expand USAID/Morocco's efforts to support the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MNEVT) to improve reading and writing outcomes at the primary school level. The activity will be carried out in partnership with the MNEVT to build their capacity to develop effective Arabic language curriculum and instructional materials and to deliver professional development programs to education personnel to improve teaching skills and better monitor student progress. Notification of this opportunity does not obligate USAID/Morocco to pay for any costs that may be incurred by interested parties for any action taken in response to issuance of this NOI. Questions or comments regarding this Notice of Intent may be addressed in writing to Craig Smith at csmith@usaid.gov and to Salya Yacoubi at syacoubi@usaid.gov   USAID/Morocco Office of Acquisition & Assistance Phone: (+212) 537 63 72 00 Ext. 7906 || Fax: (+212) 537 63 20 20 || Address: Av. Mohammed IV Km 5.7, 10170, Souissi, Rabat
Awardee: Creative Associates International, Inc. UEI: DBG1D86ZUQH4 5301 WISCONSIN AVE NW STE 700 WASHINGTON DC 20015-2015 WA USA

Title: STEM Teacher Education and School Strengthening Activity
Description: Dear Interested Party: The purpose of this pre-solicitation notice is to inform you of the following: 1. USAID/Egypt thanks you for the responses to the RFI/Sources Sought (RFI-263-00002) posted to FBO.gov on November 29, 2016. 2. The RFP is not yet ready for release. We anticipate an RFP release date the week of April 20, 2017. 3. The solicitation will be a full and open competitive procurement based on a statement of objectives. The contract will be a cost-reimbursement contract with a maximum value of $20-$25 million with a period of performance of 5 years. 4. The scope of the contract will be to provide technical assistance to support the following objectives: a. To develop, deliver, and sustain high-quality STEM teacher education and preparation programs at undergraduate and graduate levels: i. Pre-service teachers will receive quality preparation for modern STEM classrooms, thereby providing the STEM education system with a continuous supply of well-prepared STEM teachers, and raising the quality of teaching and learning in the STEM subjects at the secondary level in STEM schools; ii. In-service teachers will be able to enter post-graduate year-long certification programs in STEM Education as well as continue shorter teacher training. b. To fully institutionalize roles and processes to ensure the sustained quality of STEM schools and support the MOE to scale up STEM education nationwide: STEM high schools will be strengthened and fully institutionalized, and the Ministry of Education (MOE) will have the capacity to sustain the quality of existing STEM high schools and expand the model to additional governorates/nationwide. Those new schools will enjoy the same quality of teaching and learning, and the same level of administrative and technical support for teacher and administrator development and procurement. 5. Approximately two weeks after the RFP release date, USAID/Egypt will host a pre-proposal conference in Cairo, Egypt. Details on how to register and participate in this conference will be made available through a special notice posted on FBO.gov. The intended purpose of the conference is to: a. Describe the current USAID-sponsored STEM activity; b. Describe how the proposed new activity is different from the current activity; and c. Engage in a question and answer session with USAID/Egypt technical and contracting staff. 6. Proposals will be due approximately 3-4 weeks after the pre-proposal conference. 7. USAID/Egypt strongly encourages all interested parties to add their organization's relevant information to the "interested vendors" tab within this opportunity's FBO page to start a dialogue on potential collaboration. 8. All offerors are advised that this solicitation may be canceled or revised at any time during solicitation, selection, evaluation, negotiation and up to final award. If the solicitation is cancelled, all proposal preparation costs will be borne by the offeror.
NAICS: Educational Support Services

Title: Community Connections Program (CCP) in Belarus
Description: Pre-solicitation Notice COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS PROGRAM (CCP) IN BELARUS Solicitation Number:                 SOL-113-17-000001 Pre-solicitation Release Date:   March 15, 2017 The United States Government, represented by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), Regional Mission for Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova intends to issue a contract for the implementation of the Community Connections Program (CCP) in Belarus. USAID intends to use full and open competition for this procurement and to release the solicitation within the second quarter of U.S. fiscal year 2017. This pre-solicitation notice purpose is to provide information regarding the anticipated USAID Community Connections Program (CCP) in Belarus through a synopsis. Title:     Community Connections Program (CCP) in Belarus Goal:    The goal of the Community Connections Program (CCP) in Belarus is to support USAID/Belarus' development effort aimed to further democratic and economic reforms in Belarus by encouraging active citizen participation in democratic processes, and to promote mutual understanding among American and Belarusian people. The CCP is a cross cutting exchange program that supports USG foreign assistance priorities across sectors by introducing Belarusian civil society, private actors and public sector representatives to democratic practices and free-market values, and inspiring them to implement transformational economic and social activities in Belarus. Objectives:    The CCP objectives are: 1) to expose participants to the advantages and challenges of a democratic, free-market society; 2) to transfer modern knowledge and skills to Belarusians; and 3) to create a network of professionals who will contribute to implementing transformational economic and social activities in Belarus. Prospective Offerors are advised that this procurement is subject to internal USAID approvals and the availability of funds. This is NOT an Invitation for Bid (IFB) or a Request for Proposals (RFP) and in no way obligates the US Government to issue an RFP/IFB and/or award a contract. This notice satisfies the synopsis requirement in FAR 5.2. If a solicitation is issued, all necessary information will be supplied at the time it is posted at www.fbo.gov. Interested parties are advised to periodically monitor the above website and solicitation number for updates concerning this procurement.
NAICS: All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services

Title: HIV Prevention Advisor
Description: Botswana is among the most affected countries in the world, with a national adult HIV prevalence of 23.8% and approximately 300,000 people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA) in a country of 1.88 million. Botswana, as one of the former 15 focus countries under PEPFAR, has a strong USG presence in HIV/AIDS. USAID has a field office in Gaborone that manages activities in the areas of trade and economic growth, and environment; however, until recently USAID did not have a presence to support its HIV/AIDS activities which were managed from the Regional HIV/AIDS Program Office [RHAP] in Pretoria. In 2007, USAID hired a Director to provide technical and programmatic oversight to the USAID activities in Botswana as the first step in providing appropriate in-country support for this portfolio which has been growing in size and complexity. This position will support the USAID Director in providing oversight and support for USAID/Botswana’s HIV prevention activities and coordination with other USG partners (State Department, US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Department of Defense and Peace Corps) and collaboration with the Government of Botswana and other bi-lateral and multi-lateral donors. Specifically, USAID is supporting prevention efforts in the areas of behavior change communication, HIV testing and counseling, capacity building, male circumcision, alcohol, and gender as well as prevention for People Living with HIV/AIDS. These activities will target the general population as well as most-at-risk populations. A combination package for prevention is employed in Botswana. This is a set of interventions which, if implemented simultaneously with sufficient reach, intensity, and duration, has the potential to dramatically reduce further transmission of HIV in Botswana. The Government of Botswana (GOB) has made a commitment to achieving the goal of “Zero New Infections by 2016” and the Prevention Advisor will be charged with assisting the GOB in reaching the goals set out in the “National Operational Plan for Scaling up HIV Prevention in Botswana”.  The HIV Prevention Advisor, who will be based in Gaborone, Botswana, is recruited, hired, and funded by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) Regional HIV-AIDS Program (RHAP) for Southern Africa (which is based in Pretoria, South Africa) through the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (Emergency Plan). Supervision of this position is assigned to the USAID Director in Botswana, and the incumbent will be a key player on the inter-Agency PEPFAR team.
NAICS: All Other Personal Services

Title: Total Market Initiative for Health Product Supply in Madagascar
Description: The purpose of the Total Market Initiative for Health Product Supply (TMI-HPS) activity is to apply an integrated approach to sustainably increase the availability and accessibility of quality health products for the Malagasy people. The activity will use a total market approach (TMA) to maximize the relative strengths of public, private, and commercial actors to deliver health products that reach all beneficiaries and consumer markets. The activity will also strengthen the capacity of the Government of Madagascar (GOM) to manage supply of pharmaceuticals and health commodities; encourage the expansion of commercial actors into new markets; and support social marketing to increase demand for and coverage of essential health products.
NAICS: Administration of Public Health Programs

Title: Construction Supervision or Compliance Activity of USAID/Armenia Funded Activities
Description: This requirement is for a Blanket Purchase Agreement for Architectural and Engineering (A&E) Services for various project locations within Republic of Armenia. A&E firms and individuals shall hold all necessary licenses of the Republic of Armenia to provide the required services. The services will be for undertaking the supervision or compliance review of USAID's Implementing Partner's and construction contractor's works, which will include the following: (i) Design review and comments; Ensure that works are in compliance with the approved design and applicable laws, building codes and safety requirements; (ii) Supervision or compliance review of construction works for safety, quality, quantity (volume of works) and time control; The aim is to obtain the highest quality product, in the least time, and assure adherence to USAID approved environmental, safety and health procedures, controlling claims and moderating additional cost, and maintain a written record of the process and results; (iii) Participate in and where necessary perform interim testing of systems and system components; (iv) Participate in the final inspection and acceptance of works; (v) Work closely with USAID respective staff for coordination of activities, provide regular technical feedback on progress, schedule joint monitoring site visits; (vi) Compile and provide related documents and reports, etc. Specific deliverables and milestones will be provided by the COR for each Task Order issued under this BPA. Comment on the Contractor's Shop Drawings: The A&E Company will review the working designs and specifications to ensure that they comply with Armenian construction standards/codes and safety and environmental requirements Supervision, Compliance Oversight of Construction Contractors Works: The A&E Company shall supervise or review the construction work for compliance with the overall agreed technical quality and compliance of performance, equipment and materials, and the quality of workmanship as well as the quantity (volume of works) and time control when tasked. This shall involve compliance with the design and specifications, quality of work and changes of the program when appropriate. Compliance control shall be carried out for supplies as well as for works. Particular attention has to be paid to the compliance with safety and environmental requirements. Recommendations shall be made to USAID/Armenia either recommending acceptance or denial of the contractor's requests for extensions, changes for the approved plans and schedules. Technical Inspections: The A&E Company shall check all the technical codes and standards for the installation and construction of all systems/equipment and their compliance with approved designs, applicable laws, building codes, safety and environmental requirements. Meetings: Site progress meetings with USAID/Armenia shall be scheduled on a monthly or semi-monthly basis as requested by USAID/Armenia for each specific order. More frequent meetings will be organized during times of peak activity, if necessary. In case inaccuracies are identified during inspection visits, corrective and remedial measures will be discussed and agreed upon during the formal progress monitoring meetings. The principal items to be addressed at the project progress meetings and following monthly reports shall include but not limited to the following: • Adequacy of performed works with the initially approved design; • Discussion of identified current/potential problems, finding solutions. Testing and Commissioning: The A&E Company shall participate in the interim and final commissioning. The A&E Company shall certify final test results and witness the commissioning of the systems. Testing of all the equipment/systems installed by the construction contractor shall be carried out in accordance with the specifications. A&E Company engineers shall attend and witness final testing of equipment and systems. A. Deliverables and Deliverables Schedule For each Task Order under this BPA the Contractor shall submit the following deliverables/reports or outputs to the COR: • Construction Project Supervision or Compliance Reports: will be submitted to USAID/Armenia on a monthly basis regarding the progress of the project; quantity and quality as well as correspondence of the works performed by the construction contractor(s) with the design. Should any inconsistencies between the design and the works performed by the construction contractor, or any other problems be identified during the project monitoring, the contractor will provide unplanned reports to USAID/Armenia keeping them apprised of the problems. • Phase Reports: will be provided to USAID/Armenia upon completion of certain tasks and installation and testing of systems according to the approved schedule of works. • Project Completion Report: will be provided to USAID/Armenia upon completion and sign off of a specific project. • BPA Completion Report: will be provided to USAID/Armenia upon completion and sign off of the BPA. The lead discipline shall be a registered Architect. The term of the contract will be 1,825 calendar days from the date of contract award, or until a $500,000 maximum contract limit is reached. The daily rates will be negotiated for each calendar year. The A&E fee for any single order may not exceed $150,000. The estimated start date is December 2016. Qualifications will be reviewed by an A&E Evaluation Board to evaluate and determine the most highly qualified firms to perform the work prescribed in the Statement of Work for the BPA and the BPA's calls announced with BPA. The evaluation of the offerors will be based on the information provided in the Standard Form 330. A price proposal will be requested of the highest evaluated firm and discussions will be initiated with this firm with the intent of an award. Evaluation of proposals will be done using numerical scoring by the criteria presented below. A&E selection criteria will include (in order of importance): (1) Professional qualification of the proposed staff and consultants. Proposals shall demonstrate knowledge and experience in applying sustainability concepts and principles to facilities and infrastructures through an integrated design approach, including: water and energy conservation, pollution prevention, the use of recovered and recycled materials, waste reduction, and construction waste management practices. List only the team members who will actually perform major tasks under this contract. Qualifications should address each individual's specific contribution to the efforts contemplated by the contract. SCHEDULE A: 1) interior/exterior renovations/alterations; 2) energy efficiency/conservation designs, 3) repair and minor construction projects, 4) structural investigations and 5) seismic evaluations. SCHEDULE B: 1) water and other utility improvements, 2) site improvements, 3) general landscape, surveying and irrigation projects, 4) life safety, 5) site surveys, 6) site investigations, 7) cost estimating, 8) economic analysis required to develop and define actual costs of construction projects, 9) provide quality control and inspection/acceptance services. The firm must have experience with coordination of design disciplines for phased construction, including occupied/unoccupied and fast track projects. Projects may also require the identification of asbestos and lead-based paint. Do not list more than a total of ten (10) projects in Section F of SF Form 330. Indicate which consultants for the proposed team, if any, participated in the preparation of design documentation for the projects listed. Sustainable Design: Demonstrated success in prescribing the use of recovered materials and achieving waste reduction and energy efficiency in facility design. 2) Past performance on contracts with government agencies and private industry in terms of cost control, quality of work and compliance with performance schedules. Indicate effectiveness by listing budget/estimated construction cost, award amount, final design estimates, and construction change order rate for at least five recent projects. Briefly describe internal quality assurance and cost control procedures and indicate team members who are responsible for monitoring these processes and how you ensure the quality of work from subcontractors. List recent awards, commendations, and other performance evaluations (do not submit copies). (3) Capacity to accomplish the work in the required time. Indicate the firm's present workload and the availability of the project team (including consultants) for the specified contract performance period and indicate specialized available and prior security clearances. (4) Location in the general geographic area and knowledge of the locality of the projects. Those firms which meet the requirements described in this announcement and wish to be considered must submit one copy of SF 330 for the firm and Section E of SF330 for each consultant listed in Section G, to the address stated above by 5:00 P.M. Local Time on the due date that is shown above. Submittals received after the date and time stated herein will not be considered. Indicate solicitation number in block 3 of PART I and block 1 of PART II, Contractor Establishment Code (CEC), and /or DUNS number in block 4 of PART II, email address in block 6c. For firm with multiple offices, complete the PART II for each specific branch office seeking work. Use Section H of the SF 330 to provide any additional information desired. Personal interviews may not be scheduled prior to selection of the most highly qualified firm. SF 330s shall not exceed 30 printed pages. Double sided are two pages. Organizational charts and photographs are excluded from the 30-page count. Exception: Photographs with text will be considered one page. All information must be included in the SF 330 (cover letter, other attachments and pages in excess of the 30 page limit will not be included in the evaluation process). Firms not providing the requested information in the format directed in the synopsis will be negatively evaluated. Firms, their subsidiaries or affiliates that design or prepare specifications for a construction contract or procurement of supplies cannot provide the construction or supplies. This limitation also applies to subsidiaries and affiliates of the firm. Telegraphic and facsimile SF 330s will not be accepted. Site visits will not be arranged during the submittal period The Standard Industrial Code (SIC) is 8711 and the North American Industry Code Standard (NAICS) is 541330. The lead discipline shall be a registered Architect. Proposals must be written in English. The Offeror should submit the proposal electronically internet e-mail attachments compatible with PDF, MS Word, Excel, in a MS Windows environment. The address for the recipient of electronic proposals is ayeghiazarian@usaid.gov Government Obligation - The US Government is not obligated to make an award or to pay for any costs incurred by the offeror in preparation of a proposal in response hereto.
POC Information: Armen E. Yeghiazarian | Armen E. Yeghiazarian
Awardee: HAMKAR DESIGN UEI: MV82M4NKHKQ3 Building 10a, Apt. 29 3 Davidashen District ARM
NAICS: Engineering Services

Title: General Development Officer
Description: The GDO serves as senior manager for the USAID programs supporting the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), the Development Grants Program (DGP) and Public-Private Partnership (PPP) efforts. S/he represents USAID to the Embassy and other USG Agencies, to Government of Angola counterparts, and to USG implementing partners. S/he leads program development, management, implementation, day-to-day coordination of administrative management for USAID activities. S/he is the lead agency point-of-contact for USAID with the PEPFAR Coordinator and the other USG partners that support PEPFAR, including the Office of the Global AIDS Coordinator (OGAC), Center for Disease Control (CDC) and the Department of Defense (DOD). Duties and responsibilities include strategy development parameters, program planning and development, supervision of USAID staff, and oversight of or direct activity management of USAID grants, contracts and cooperative agreements.
NAICS: All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services

Title: PEPFAR Country Coordinator
Description: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) - the U.S. Government initiative to help save the lives of those impacted by HIV/AIDS around the world - is the largest commitment by any nation in history to combat a single disease internationally. PEPFAR investments also help alleviate suffering from other diseases across the global health spectrum. PEPFAR is driven by a shared responsibility among donor and partner nations and others to make smart investments to save lives. Thanks in large part to U.S. leadership, tremendous progress has been made in the fight against global AIDS. PEPFAR has supported life-saving antiretroviral treatment for more than 7 million men, women and children worldwide as of September 30, 2013. PEPFAR supported HIV testing and counseling for more than 74.3 million people in FY 2016, providing a critical entry point to prevention, treatment, and care. In addition, life-saving antiretroviral treatment (ART) for nearly 11.5 million adults and 1.1 million children, were provided through PEPFAR assistance in Fiscal Year (FY) 2016. PEPFAR provided antiretroviral medications to prevent mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) of the virus. Due to this PEPFAR support, nearly 2 million babies were born HIV-free. By September 30, 2016, PEPFAR had also supported more than 11.7 million voluntary medical male circumcision (VMMC) procedures in east and southern Africa. Now in its third phase, PEPFAR is continuing to focus on the transition from an emergency response to building sustainable programs. These programs are country-owned and country-driven and address HIV/AIDS with a broader context of health and development. PEPFAR's program builds on past strengths and increases efficiencies by scaling up effective interventions and ensuring value.
NAICS: All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services

Title: Early Grade Reading Activity
Description: Pre-Solicitation Notice for the Early Grade Reading Activity in the West Bank The USAID West Bank and Gaza Mission contemplates issuing a Request for Proposals (RFP) to support the Palestinian Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MOEHE) to enhance learning outcomes for Palestinian children at the primary level by improving Arabic reading instruction, policies and practices at the government, community and school levels. The Mission contemplates achievement of the objectives via a Cost Plus Fixed Fee (CPFF) Completion Type contract. More specifically, the activity may include the following illustrative interventions: 1) Improve early grade reading and introduce targeted learning materials that are integrated into grades 1-4 in public school classrooms in the West Bank; 2) Prepare MOEHE teachers and administrators to provide effective reading instruction through in service, induction and pre-service training, mentoring and supervision; 3) Encourage community engagement and participation to support increased student reading outcomes and school accountability; 4) Support MOEHE efforts to institutionalize early grade reading policies, standards and assessments. Subject to USAID internal approvals of this program, the anticipated issuance date of the RFP is targeted for February 2017. This notice does not obligate USAID to release a solicitation or award a contract nor does it commit the Government to pay for costs incurred in the preparation and submission of a proposal in pursuit thereof.

Title: Decentralization and Local Administration Reform (DLAR)
Description: The United States Agency for International Development in Egypt (USAID/Egypt) is in the process of designing a new stand-alone activity and statement of objectives (SOO) for Decentralization and Local Administration Reform (DLAR). The anticipated contract type is Cost-plus-fixed-fee completion. The budget range for both base and option activities is between $18 and $23 million.  The purpose of this RFI is to: 1) offer the opportunity for interested organizations to provide information, opinions, recommendations on approaches for implementation and ask questions on the attached draft Statement of Objectives (SOO), draft evaluation criteria and draft instructions for the development of the Technical proposal; 2) conduct market research, to determine interest; and 3) give an anticipated time table for the solicitation and announce a pre-solicitation conference. Information obtained through this RFI/Sources Sought will be held in confidence and will not be disclosed to the public unless specifically requested by responding sources or if questions asked will assist USAID solicitation process. The purpose of this activity is to improve the effectiveness, transparency and accountability of local government to respond to citizen priorities. The Government of Egypt’s (GOE) vision is to decentralize Government resources and authorities to bring key decisions closer to citizens, allowing for more effective citizen-government interaction. Assistance will support the GOE at both the national level and in select governorates. Amendment#1 :  The purpose of this amendment to the Notice is to specify the date and time of the pre-solicitation conference to be: Date: Sunday March 19, 2017 Time: 10 am to 2:00 pm Cairo local time (including breaks) Location: USAID/Egypt 1/A Nady El Etisalat St. Off El-laselky St. New Maadi Cairo Egypt Postal Code: 11435  Amendment # 2: The purpose of this amendment # 2 is to notify those who expressed interest in attending the pre-solicitation conference, originally planned to take place on March 19, 2017, that it will be postponed for two weeks. The new date of the pre-solicitation conference will be announced later through this RFI by March 26, 2017. To those who expressed interest to attend the pre-solicitation conference, please note that we suggest that the number of attendees to be from two to three persons. For those who plan to have more than three attendees, please explain the need by responding to democracy@usaid.gov. Please note that this amendment does not extend the original response date of the RFI that was March 08, 2017.

Title: USPSC - Disability Rights Advisor, GS-12, Step 4
Description: USAID is seeking offers from qualified persons to provide personal services as a Disability Rights Advisor under contract, as described in this solicitation. This PSC position is in the Center of Excellence on Democracy, Human Rights and Governance (DRG) Empowerment and Inclusion (EI) Division which leads efforts on programming for vulnerable populations.  These programs work to reduce risks to vulnerable populations and to reinforce the capacities of communities, local civil society organizations, and governments to provide services and protection for vulnerable groups.  The programs help vulnerable and marginalized populations gain access to opportunities that support their full participation in society.  The Division provides leadership on issues such as assistive technology, physical rehabilitation, trauma and torture, children in adversity, and disability.

Title: Presolicitation Notice for the Macedonia Media Support Activity
Description: Dear Prospective Offerors: The purpose of this notice is to comply with the synopses and pre-solicitation notice requirements of FAR 5.2 - Synopses of Proposed Contract Actions. Any solicitation resulting from this notice will be handled in accordance with FAR 5.102(d); therefore, availability of the solicitation package is limited to the following electronic medium: FEDBIZOPPS web page (http://www.fbo.gov/). The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) for Macedonia intends to issue a Request for Proposals (RFP) to implement the project described below. The purpose of the solicitation is to obtain the services for the Project entitled Media Support Activity. The primary objective of the MSA Activity is to ensure that citizens have access to balanced, independent, and professional journalism that provides fact-based information about issues of public concern. MSA will be part of USAID’s overall media portfolio and has three complementary and mutually reinforcing objectives. These are to:  I. Create sustained space for investigative journalism and improved opportunities for journalists and civil society organizations to access publicly available data to report on issues of public concern;  II. Create media literacy  amongst the public that allows citizens to defend their access to free information, critically assess the media messages they receive, and participate in public policy dialogues;  and III. Protect journalists and media organizations’ rights and safety. The media portfolio, of which MSA is a part, also has a fourth objective, which is to increase pluralism and transparency in the media environment through content production, Offerors are advised that this is NOT a formal Request for Proposal (RFP) and in no way obligates the US Government to issue a RFP and/or award a contract. Issuance of the RFP solicitation and award of a contract are subject to availability of funds and other internal USAID approvals. The information contained herein is released for wide dissemination to all parties. The information is subject to modification and is in no way binding to the Government.  You are advised to regularly check the site noted above for future updates or information and look out for a formal RFP. Interested offerors are encouraged to register themselves as an interested vendor.  DO NOT SEND ANY PROPOSALS OR QUESTIONS UNTIL THE FORMAL RFP IS POSTED. USAID bears no responsibility for data errors resulting from this transmission.
NAICS: All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services

Title: Building Foundations Program
Description: The United States Government, represented by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)/West Bank and Gaza (WBG) intends to solicit proposals from qualified U.S. organizations interested in providing construction services for projects throughout the West Bank and Gaza. Contract(s) resulting from this solicitation will be Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity Contracts (IDIQs) with Task Orders funded and awarded individually thereafter. The U. S. Government anticipates awarding approximately 4-6 contracts under the unrestricted competition and reserve one (1) IDIQ contract award for small business as a result of this Solicitation. The Agency reserves the right to award more or less awards than the anticipated number of contracts stated above. Task orders will be awarded to IDIQ contractors through a competitive, fair opportunity process as described at FAR 16.505. There is no guarantee as to the number of task orders that any IDIQ holder will receive. The maximum combined contract ceiling resulting from this RFP will be $500,000,000. Each successful IDIQ holder will be eligible to compete for task orders until the shared ceiling for all contracts is reached. The purpose of the Building Foundations IDIQ contract is to obtain services to implement Task Orders for the construction, rehabilitation and/or improvement of infrastructure works throughout the West Bank and Gaza.   It is anticipated that the work, in general terms, will include the following: 1.     Transportation networks such as primary and secondary roads, bridges and/or other transportation infrastructure. 2.     Water systems infrastructure including supply, storage, treatment, transmission and distribution facilities, drilling and equipping deep ground water wells, and construction and rehabilitation of pump stations; 3.     Solid waste infrastructure including solid waste collection, storage, management and disposal, wastewater treatment and reuse facilities. This may include new wastewater treatment plants, commissioning and start-up of the new plants, and operation and maintenance for periods to be specified in respective RFTOPs. 4.     Vertical structures such as schools, clinics, health facilities, government buildings and facilities, sports facilities, warehouses, food storage facilities, youth and sports centers, and other buildings designed to benefit the public interest. 5.     Electric power sector infrastructure to include alternative, sustainable and/or traditional forms of power generation (such as wind turbines, photovoltaic, solar thermal, geothermal, and fossil-fuel-fired thermal power plants), and electricity transmission and distribution systems in the West Bank and Gaza.   6.     Design-Build and/or Design-Build-Operate of facilities and infrastructure in any of the sectors contemplated in this Statement of Work. Engineering studies and design work under this IDIQ contract will primarily be carried out by a separate A&E firm as described in Section C.7 of this RFP, and design capacity is not expected to represent a substantial portion of the work under this Contract. 7.     Procurements identified by USAID needed to support USAID objectives that will be conducted by IDIQ contractors on a competitive basis.  These may include the procurement of equipment and/or materials, including but not limited to construction heavy equipment, electrical, mechanical and any other equipment identified at a later stage by USAID.  8.     Any other similar infrastructure construction activities that may emerge to further USAID development objectives in response to the rapidly evolving political environment.
NAICS: Other Heavy and Civil Engineering Construction

Title: USAID Green Growth Activity
Description: The U.S. Government, represented by the United States Agency for International Development, Mission to Ethiopia (USAID/Ethiopia), contemplates issuing a Request for Proposal (RFP) to award a single, Cost-Plus-Fixed -Fee (CPFF) completion type contract for the implementation of the USAID Green Growth Activity. The purpose of this activity is to support the Government of Ethiopia (GOE) through demand-driven technical assistance to increase the public sector’s core competencies and resources to support the implementation of Ethiopia’s Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) and climate objectives within its Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP). The objective of this contract is to support the GOE build and institutionalize the systems and capacity needed to deliver on its INDC and climate-resilient, green economy (CRGE) goals within its GTP.   The tentative performance period is 5 years. The solicitation and any subsequent award will be conducted in accordance with FAR Part15, and other relevant sections of FAR and AIDAR. The tentative applicable NAICS Code is: 541990 All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services. All qualified offerors are invited to provide their proposal. Offerors are encouraged to check  https://www.fbo.gov regularly to obtain additional information on this requirement.   This notice is for informational purposes only and is not a request for offers. Title: Safe, Affordable, and Effective Medicines for Ukrainians (SAFEMed)
Description: Pre-solicitation Notice Solicitation Number: SOL-121-17-000005 Activity Title: Safe, Affordable, and Effective Medicines for Ukrainians (SAFEMed) Pre-Solicitation Release Date: December 21, 2016 USAID/Ukraine contemplates award of a Cost-Plus-Fixed-Fee (CPFF) Completion type contract for a period of five (5) years from the date of award. The total estimated cost is from $10 million - $15 million. The period of performance will tentatively be 2017 through 2022. The purpose of the Safe, Affordable, and Effective Medicines for Ukrainians (SAFEMed) activity is to strengthen the pharmaceutical system in Ukraine to ensure transparency and cost-efficiency for desired health outcomes.  This contract will support the ongoing efforts of the Government of Ukraine (GoU) and its civil society partners to transform its healthcare system to effectively meet the needs of its citizens. The specific objectives of the activity are: 1. Pharmaceutical sector governance strengthened. 2. Pharmaceutical sector financing optimized. 3. Availability and appropriate use of essential medications increased. Prospective Offerors are advised that this procurement is subject to internal USAID approvals and the availability of funds.
